introduction.p: In Principia, Newton presented his three laws of motion, and also stated the law of gravitation. The law of gravitation states that there is an attractive force between all objects that depends on their masses and distances.

The magnitude of the gravitational force F between two particles of masses m_1 and m_2 separated by a distance r is given by
F = G_N\, \dfrac{m_1 m_2}{r^2},
where G_N is a universal constant, called gravitational constant. Do not confuse this G_N with acceleration due to gravity g, although sometimes we write G for G_N. The value of G_N has been determined experimentally to be
G_N = 6.67428\times10^{-11}\ \text{N.(m/kg)}^2.
Constant G_N is considered to be truly universal, being same between any two objects anywhere in the universe, although there has been speculation that its value may have changed over time.

The force is very weak as you can tell if you calculate force between two 1\text{-kg} objects 1\text{-m} apart. It will be
F = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N}.
Experimental verification of the law in a lab experiment was done by Henry Cavendish, who made use of a very sensitive torsion balance, now called the Cavendish balance, to detect small forces. Modern versions of Canvendish experiment are routinely perfomed by advanced physics students.

subsection.title: Applying the Law of Gravitation to Spherical Bodies
subsection.p: Eq. is for force between point particles. To get the formula for gravitational force between extended bodies, we need to use mathematics to figure out the net force between all particles of the two bodies.

Mathematics (Calculus) shows that the gravitaional force between two spherical bodies that are outside of each other has the same form as Eq. provided the distance r is center-to-center distance . For instance, the force between Earth and Sun will be
F = G_N\, \dfrac{M_{\text{Sun}} M_{\text{Earth}}}{r_{\text{ES}}^2},
where r_{\text{ES}} is the distance from the center of the Sun to the center of the Earth.
Similarly, the gravitaitonal force of Earth on a satellite around Earth will be based on the distance from the center of the Earth and the satellite, and not just the altitude of the satellite.

But, how about force on an object at a point inside a spherical body? For instance, what will be the force on a miner deep inside the Earth? Math shows that, only the mass of the sphere that is within the distance to the object matters.

Say, an object of mass m inside Earth is at a distance d from the center of Earth. The surprising discovery of the mathematics of spherical bodies is that the force of Earth on such a body will be from only those masses of Earth that are within a distance d from the center. That is, effectively Earth will be of radius d rather than R_E.
F = G_N\, \dfrac{m M_d}{d^2},
where M_d is the part of Earth that is within a distance d from its center.

One of the consequences of this result is that if you sit inside a spherical shell, the gravitational force on you will be zero no matter where you sit, since there is no mass within your distance from the center.

statement.p: Evaluate the gravitational force in the following situations:
(a) between two 5-kg spherical steel balls separated by a center-to-center distance of 15\text{ cm}, and,

(b) the Sun and the planet Neptune which have an average separation of 30.15\text{ AU}. M_\text{Sun} \approx 2.0\times 10^{30}\text{ kg}, M_\text{Neptune} \approx 1.0\times 10^{26}\text{ kg} and 1\text{ AU} = 1.496\times 10^8\text{ km}.

hint.p: (a) and (b) : Use formulas for spherical bodies.

solution.p:
(a) We use the formulas given.
F \amp = G_N \dfrac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}, \amp = 6.67\times 10^{-11} \dfrac{ 5\times 5}{0.15^2} = 7.41\times 10^{-8}\text{ N}.

(b) We use the formulas given.
F \amp = G_N \dfrac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}, \amp = 6.67\times 10^{-11} \dfrac{2.0\times 10^{30}\times 1.0\times 10^{26}}{(30.15\times 1.496\times 10^8\times 10^3)^2}, \amp = 6.56\times 10^{20}\text{ N}.

subsection.title: Applying the Law of Gravitation to Arbitrary Bodies
subsection.p: If the distance between two bodies is large compared to their sizes, the bodies can be replaced by point masses and then we can use the same form of the law as given in Eq. for point particles. The force of attraction between non-spherical objects which are not far apart compared to their sizes is complicated and can only be computed by dividing the bodies into smaller parts and vectorially summing up the forces between every pair of masses.

example.title: Newton's Apple
example.p: It is interesting to note that a straightforward analysis of the falling of an apple and the continuous falling of the Moon towards the Earth can lead one to the discovery of the inverse distance square part of the universal law of gravitation. Although, Newton did not come upon the universal law of gravitation in this way, the analysis is none-the-less instructive, and will be presented here.

From the observations on freely falling objects near the Earth, you know that the apple falls with an acceleration of 9.81\text{ m/s}^2. From observations on the Moon, i.e. from the distance to the Moon and its time period, it is also known that the Moon has a centripetal acceleration of 0.00272\text{ m/s}^2 in its circular orbit about Earth.

statement.p: Find gravitational forces between objects in the following situations.
(a) Two spherical lead balls of masses 10 kg each separated by center-to-center distance of 10 cm.
(b) Two people of height approximately 1.5 m and masses 100 kg and 60 kg separated by a distance of 2 m.
(d) A satellite of mass 1000 kg in orbit 200 km above the Earth; use mass of the Earth = 5.96\times 10^{24}\text{ kg}, and mean radius of the Earth = 6.37\times 10^6\text{ m}.

hint.p: (a) force same as point objects, (b) Too complicated to calculate, (c) approximately same as point objects, (d) same as a spherical object and a point object outside of the sphere.

solution.p: (a) I have stated above that a spherical object acts same as a point particle as far as gravitation outside the sphere is concerned. Therefore, the force between the spherical lead balls can be easily computed giving the following magnitude. F = \left(6.67\times 10^{-11} \right) \times \dfrac{10\ \times 10\ }{\left( 0.1\ \right)^2} = 6.67\times 10^{-7}\ \textrm{N}.

(b) Since people are not spherical objects, and since their separation is not too great compared to their sizes, we cannot use the same form of the law of gravitation as given for the point particles. If we use the formula given, we will only get some rough estimate, not an exact answer for the magnitude of the force. F(\text{CRUDE IDEA}) = \left(6.67\times 10^{-11} \right) \times \dfrac{100\ \times 100\ }{\left( 2\ \textrm{m}\right)^2} = 1.0\times 10^{-8}\ \textrm{N}.

(c) In this part, the people are separated by more than 10-times their sizes. Therefore approximating them as spheres will not give us too different a result than an exact result. Although the result of spherical approximation for a person will not give an exact result, but we expect the result to be more precise here than it was in part (b). The magnitude of the force is F \approx \left(6.67\times 10^{-11} \right) \times \dfrac{100\ \times 100\ }{\left( 20\ \right)^2} = 1.0\times 10^{-10}\ \textrm{N}.

(d) Although, the satellite is not a spherical object, it is far away from the Earth compared to the size of the satellite. Therefore, we can treat the satellite as a point mass. This gives the following for the magnitude of the force on the satellite. F =\left(6.67\times 10^{-11} \right) \times \dfrac{5.97\times10^{24}\ \times 1000\ }{\left( 6.37\times10^6\ +0.200\times10^6\ \right)^2} = 9.2\times 10^{3}\ \textrm{N}.

statement.p: (a) Find the gravitational force between Earth and Sun. (b) What is the magnitude of acceleration of Earth caused by this force acting on Earth? (c) What is the magnitude of acceleration of Sun caused by this force acting on Sun?
Data: M_\text{E} = 5.96\times 10^{24}\text{ kg}, M_\text{S} = 2.0\times 10^{30}\text{ kg}, r_\text{ES} = 1.5\times 10^{11}\text{ m}.

hint.p: (a) Use formula. (b) Apply F=ma on Earth. (c) Apply F=ma on Sun.

solution.p:
(b) Dividing by mass of Earth will give the magnitude of acceleration.
a = \dfrac{F}{M_\text{E}} = \dfrac{ 3.53 \times 10^{22}\text{ N} }{ 5.96\times 10^{24}\text{ kg}} = 5.92\times 10^{-3}\text{ m/s}^2.

(c) Dividing by mass of Sun will give the magnitude of acceleration.
a = \dfrac{F}{M_\text{S}} = \dfrac{ 3.53 \times 10^{22}\text{ N} }{ 2\times 10^{30}\text{ kg}} = 1.77\times 10^{-8}\text{ m/s}^2.

statement.p: A satellite is to be placed in a geocentric circular orbit about Earth. Find the altitude of the circular orbit above Earth.

hint.p: Use centripetal acceleration of the uniform circular motion. You get started by comuting the speed obtained by dividing the circumference by time of one day, the time it takes the satelite go once around in its geocentric orbit.

solution.p: A geocentric orbit means that the satellite has the same time period as the time period of the rotation of Earth. When a satellite is in a geocentric orbit, the satellite appears at the same spot above the Earth. These satellites are used for telecommunications.

exercise.title: Gravitational Force on an Object by Two Other Objects - Vector Nature

sidebyside.p: Three spherical bodies are located at the corners of a right-angled triangle as shown. You may use the following values: m_1=200\text{ kg}, m_2=400\text{ kg}, m_3=300\text{ kg}, a=4\text{ m}, b=2\text{ m}.

statement.p: (a) What are the magnitude and direction of the net gravitational force on 1 by 2 and 3?
(b) What are the magnitude and direction of the net gravitational force on 2 by 1 and 3?
(c) What are the magnitude and direction of the net gravitational force on 3 by 1 and 2?

hint.p: (a), (b), (c): Find magnitudes of the forces and use components to add the vectors to obtain the net force.

answer.p: (a) 10.5\times 10^{-7}\text{ N} at 72^\circ counterclockwise from positive x axis. (b) 7.1\times 10^{-7}\text{ N} at 14.6^\circ clockwise from negative x axis. (c) 12.2\times 10^{-7}\text{ N} at 73^\circ clockwise from positive x axis.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: Looks like we should use the unit of 10^{-7}\text{ N} . We will call this unit \text{N*} to save space.

We use angle \theta to indicate the direction. The counterclockwise angle from the positive x axis is
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{10.0}{3.3} \right) = 72^\circ.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
Lets denote the magnitudes of forces on 2 by F_{12} and F_{32} . We have already worked the magnitude of the force between 1 and 2, which we had called F_{21}.
F_{12} = F_{21} = 3.3 \text{ N*}.
The other force on 2 is
F_{32} \amp = G_N\dfrac{m_2 m_3}{c^2} \amp = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\dfrac{400\times300}{2^2 + 4^2} = 4.0\times 10^{-7}\text{ N}.
That is F_{32} = 4.0\text{ N*}. To add these two forces we use the components.
F_{12,x} \amp = -3.3\text{ N*}, F_{12,y} \amp = 0, F_{32,x} \amp = -4.0\times \dfrac{4}{\sqrt{2^2+4^2}} = -3.6\text{ N*}, F_{32,y} \amp = 4.0\times \dfrac{2}{\sqrt{2^2+4^2}} = 1.8\text{ N*},
Therefore, the components of the net force are
F_{\text{net},x} = -3.3 -3.6 = -6.9\text{ N*}, F_{\text{net},y} = 0 + 1.8 = + 1.8\text{ N*}.

sidebyside.p:
The magnitude of this force is
F_{\text{net}} = \sqrt{ 6.9^2 + 1.8^2 } = 7.1\text{ N*} = 7.1\times 10^{-7}\text{ N}.
The direction is in the second quadrant with clockwise angle with respect to the negative x axis give by
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1.8}{6.9} \right) = 14.6^\circ.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) We have worked out the magnitudes F_{13} and F_{23} already as F_{31} and F_{32}.
F_{13} \amp = F_{31} = 10.0 \text{ N*}. F_{23} \amp = F_{32} = 4.0 \text{ N*}.
We also know their components as per Newton's third law.
F_{13,x} \amp = 0, F_{13,y} \amp = -10.0\text{ N*}, F_{23,x} \amp = - F_{32,x} = 3.6\text{ N*}, F_{23,y} \amp = - F_{32,y} =-1.8\text{ N*},
Therefore, the net force on 3 has the following components.
F_{\text{net},x} = 0 + 3.6 = 3.6 \text{ N*}, F_{\text{net},y} = -10.0 - 1.8 = - 11.8\text{ N*}.
The magnitude of this force is
F_{\text{net}} = \sqrt{ 3.^2 + 11.8^2 } = 12.2\text{ N*} = 12.2\times 10^{-7}\text{ N}.
The direction is in the fourth quadrant with clockwise angle with respect to the positive x axis give by
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{11.8}{3.6} \right) = 73^\circ.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Gravitational Force Between a Ball and a Rod

statement.p: A spherical ball of mass m and radius R is at one end of a uniform thin rod of mass M and length L as shown in . What is the magnitude of the gravitational force between them?

hint.p: Break up the rod into infinitesimal elements and set up an integral.

solution.p: We place the sphere with its center at the origin and the rod along x axis as shown in . Now consider the force on the sphere by an infinitesimal element of the rod between x and x+dx. The mass in the element dx=\lambda dx, where \lambda = M/L, the linear mass density.

dF = G_N\dfrac{1}{x^2}\, m\,\dfrac{M}{L} dx.
We need to integrate this from x=R to x=R+L.
F \amp = G_N \dfrac{mM}{L}\, \int_{R}^{R+L}\dfrac{1}{x^2}\, dx, \amp = G_N \dfrac{mM}{L}\, \left(\dfrac{1}{R} - \dfrac{1}{R+L}\right). \amp = G_N \dfrac{mM}{R(R+L)}.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Gravitational Force Between a Ball and a Rod with Ball Placed Above Rod

statement.p: A spherical ball of mass m and radius R is at above the middle of a uniform thin rod of mass M and length L as shown in . What is the magnitude of the gravitational force between them and direction of the force on the sphere?

hint.p: Due to symmetry only the vertical component is non-zero.

answer.p: Magnitude \dfrac{ G_N m M }{ D \sqrt{D^2 + L^2/4} } and direction towards the center of the rod.

solution.p: We place the mass of the sphere at its center and examine the force on this mass by two infintesimal elements of rod symmetrically placed as shown in . Note that the direction of the two forces is such that the sum of their horizontal components is zero. Therefore, we need to find only the vertical component.

The y component of force on the sphere by a small element between x and x + dx is
dF_y = -G_N \dfrac{m\, dM}{x^2 + D^2}\, \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{ x^2 + D^2 } }.
The infinitesimal mass, dM = (M/L)dx .We integrate this from x = -L/2 to x = L/2.
F_y \amp = -\int_{\text{rod}} G_N \dfrac{m\, dM}{x^2 + D^2}\, \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{ x^2 + D^2 } }, \amp = -\dfrac{G_N m M D}{L} \int_{-L/2}^{L/2} \dfrac{1}{ \left( x^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} }\,dx, \amp = -\dfrac{2G_N m M D}{L} \int_{0}^{L/2} \dfrac{1}{ \left( x^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} }\,dx, \amp = -\dfrac{2G_N m M D}{L} \dfrac{ L/2 }{ D^2 \sqrt{D^2 + L^2/4} }, \amp = -G_N \dfrac{ m M }{ D \sqrt{D^2 + L^2/4} }.
Therefore, the force on the sphere has magnitude \dfrac{ G_N m M }{ D \sqrt{D^2 + L^2/4} } and direction towards the center of the rod.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Gravitational Force Between a Ball and a Ring with Ball Placed Above the Center of Ring

sidebyside.p: There is a small sphere of mass m at a height D from the center of a uniform ring of radius R and mass M. Find the gravitational force on the sphere.

answer.p: \dfrac{G_N m M D}{ \left( D^2 + R^2 \right)^{3/2} } towards the center of the ring.

sidebyside.p:
Looking at force from two elements of the ring that are at the diagonally opposite sides shows us that only the vertical component is non-zero. The magnitude of the force from an element of the ring on the sphere is
dF = G_N \dfrac{m\, (M/L) dl}{ D^2 + R^2}

solution.p:
Let z axis be pointed up. Then, z component of the gravitational force from an element of the ring of size dl is
dF_z = - dF\, \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{D^2 + R^2} },
which is independent of the location of the element on the ring. When we integrate this aroiund the ring, we will get
F_z = - G_N \dfrac{m M D}{ \left( D^2 + R^2 \right)^{3/2} }.
Therefore, the magnitude of the force on the sphere is \dfrac{G_N m M D}{ \left( D^2 + R^2 \right)^{3/2} } towards the center of the ring.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Gravitational Force Between a Ball and a Disk with Ball Placed Above the Center of Disk

sidebyside.p: There is a small sphere of mass m at a height D from the center of a uniform disk of radius R and mass M. Find the gravitational force on the sphere.

hint.p: Build the solution from the solution of a ring between r and r+dr.

answer.p: \dfrac{2 G_N m M D}{R^2} \left( \dfrac{1}{D} - \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{D^2 + R^2}} \right) towards the center of the ring.

sidebyside.p:
We will build the solution of the disk from the solution of a ring between r and r+dr. The mass in the infinitesimal ring will be
dM = \dfrac{M}{\pi R^2}\, 2\pi r dr,
since area of the ring is 2\pi r dr. From symmetry, we also know that only the vertical component of the force is non-zero. Let dF_z denote the z component of the ring. From the ring solution we have
